subject: RE: [junit] JUnit for EJBs
msgSnippet: if you re running the swing or awt version, make sure you uncheck the reload box and run the test again.  it s explained in the junit FAQ. ... From: Lieve
messageBody:
if you're running the swing or awt version, make sure you uncheck the
reload box and run the test again. it's explained in the junit FAQ.

-----Original Message-----
From: Lieve Laporte [mailto:lieve.laporte@...]
Sent: Tuesday, May 29, 2001 1:54 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] JUnit for EJBs


Shaun,

Putting in the -noloading option indeed solved the problem.
Thanks a lot!

Lieve

----- Original Message -----
From: <Ext-Shaun.OHagan@...>
To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Tuesday, May 29, 2001 9:55 AM
Subject: RE: [junit] JUnit for EJBs


> Hi Lieve,
>
> I've seen this issue with the junit gui and presumably it's related to
the
> classloader features often discussed on the forum. I put in the
-noload
> thingy and the cast error went away.
>
> Regards,
>
> Shaun O'Hagan
> London UK.
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: ext Lieve Laporte [mailto:lieve.laporte@...]
> Sent: Tuesday, May 29, 2001 8:40 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] JUnit for EJBs
>
>
> Hello,
>
> I've tried to use JUnit for testing EJBs on Weblogic server, but this
> doesn't seem to work: I always get a java.lang.ClassCastException:
> ...BeanHomeImpl_WLStub, when trying to call the bean's home interface.
This
> isn't the case when I test the EJB using another Java client. Can
anyone
> explain why this problem occurs?
>
> Thanks,
>
> Lieve
